segments.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I know, it went out of style, didn't it?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It's all right.  It's a good thing.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You know, it's lovely here, the air is sweet.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You're not sorry you came?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: No, not sorry.  But, um. But I'm not gonna stay.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Why?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: For one thing, your mother as much as told me to go.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Oh.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You saw that.  I mean and then, well, you've been kind of, um--
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: What?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: The trouble is, I planned on sort of sneaking up on you on a period of a week or so.  But they take it for granted that we're all set.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I knew they would, your mother anyway.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: How'd you know?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, from her point of view, why else would I come?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Oh.  Would you want to?  I guess you know, this is why I asked you to come.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I guess this is why I came.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I have no imagination.  That's all I know to tell you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I'm embarrassing you and I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I wanted some place we'd never been before.  A place where we'd be brand new to each other.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You feel wrong here, don't you?  This yard, this chair.  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to have to win you away from anything.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Oh, Chris, I've been ready for a long, long time.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: And he's gone forever.  You're sure?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I almost got married two years ago.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Why didn't you?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, you started to write me
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You felt something that far back?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Every day since.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Ann, why didn't you let me know?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, I was waiting for you.  I mean, till then you never wrote and when you did, what did you say?  I mean, you can sure be ambiguous sometimes, you know?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Give me a kiss, Anne.  Give me a-
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: God, I kissed Annie.  How long--how long I've been waiting to kiss you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  I mean, all I did was sit and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Oh, Annie, we're gonna live now.  I'm gonna make you so happy.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Not like that you're not.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I kissed you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  What is it?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Let's drive someplace.  I want to be alone with you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: No.  What is it, Chris. Your mother?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No.  Nothing like that.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, what's wrong?  I mean, even in your letters there was some--something ashamed.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yeah, I suppose I have been.  But it's going from me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You've gotta tell me.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't know how to start.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It wouldn't work this way.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It's all mixed up with so many other things.  You remember overseas, I was in charge of a company?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yeah, sure.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well, I lost them.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: How many?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Just about all.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: gee.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It takes some time for a guy to toss that off.  'Cause they weren't just men.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: For instance, this one time, it had been raining several days and this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks.  I put them in pocket.  It's only a little thing, but those are the kind of guys I had.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  I mean, a little more selfish and they'd have been here today.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I got this idea watching 'em go down.  Everything was being destroyed, see, but it seemed that one new thing was made.  A sort of responsibility.  Man for man. You know what I mean?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: To show that, to bring that onto the Earth again, like some kind of monument and everyone can feel it standing behind him and it would make a difference to him.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Then I came back and it was incredible.  There was no meaning in it here. I mean, the whole thing to them seemed like it's sort of a bus accident.  I went to work with Dad and that rat race again.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: And I felt what you said, ashamed somehow 'cause nobody had changed at all.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive to open the new bank book, drive the new car, see the new refrigerator.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I mean, you can take those things out of a war, but when you drive that car, you've gotta realize that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.  You've gotta be a little better because of it.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Otherwise all you have is really loot and there's blood on it.  And I didn't want to take any of that.  And I guess that included you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Do you still feel that way?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I want you now Annie.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: 'Cause you mustn't feel that way.  Because you have a right to everything you have, Chris.  Everything, you understand that?  Me too.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I mean, and your money, there's- there's nothing wrong with your money.  I mean, your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  A man should be paid for that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I know Annie.  I'm gonna make a fortune for you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What'll I do with a fortune?
segments.speaker: F
